question: By the way ... And what do you call these?
answer: Ja-shwa tsway. These are lips.

question: Indeed they are. Deadly little things. And what do you call these? The Gang of Two?
answer: Stop it!

question: I was just getting to the interesting part!
answer: We've already done the interesting part. Do you forget?

question: Remind me.
answer: Sakwa!

question: Is that Mandarin, or Cantonese?
answer: Mandarin. You jerk. I'm late. I have to get dressed.

question: Hello - Hello.
answer: Hello, James. I hope I'm interrupting something important.

question: Not at all, Moneypenny. I was just brushing up on a little Chinese.
answer: I'm sure she is, James. But I'm afraid you'll have to 'kiss off' the rest of your lessons this afternoon.

question: Moneypenny... Here I was, finally getting a feel for a new tongue -
answer: Four o'clock. M will meet you in the conference room.

question: 4:30. It may take me a little longer to wrap things up here.
answer: Four o'clock. Don't be late.

question: Tsi tien, Chien-penny.
answer: Ah, James. You always were a cunning linguist... Au revoir, mon cher. Don't ask.

question: Tsi tien, Professor Wu. Nothing like a little imperialism to promote loyalty among the faithful. Yes, M. Interesting presentation.
answer: Interesting video tape.

question: They point, I shoot.
answer: Do you have a pen? I just got promoted and don't have my new cards yet.

question: Of course.
answer: ... Does this do anything?

question: Depends what number you write. Married?
answer: Happily.

question: ... Kids?
answer: Three. You? Married?

question: No.
answer: I didn't think so. Here. I gave you my assistant's phone number. If it's urgent, she knows where to reach me.

question: Thanks. Take care -
answer: You too.

question: Moneypenny! We've got to stop meeting like this. They may be on to us.
answer: Hello, James. Enjoy your meeting?

question: In the darkest moments, it's what I live for. Especially since I've heard how much you like to watch... On the hidden camera.
answer: By the way, James

question: Moneypenny! How indiscreet! Have you ever known me to kiss and tell?
answer: Actually, I've never known you to do either... But -

question: - We all want what we can't have?
answer: Not all of us, 007.

question: What - no lust for adventure?
answer: No, 007. It's just that I've learned from personal experience - that when we get what we want - Somehow the reality is never as... Satisfying as the fantasy. Don't keep M waiting.

question: Of course. Minister Johnstone. Only what I read in the newspapers.
answer: His newspapers?

question: Occasionally, yes. British media mogul. Born in Hong Kong; controls newspapers, TV, radio, cable, satellites; books, magazines, movies, computer software. Theme parks. 'Able to topple governments with a single story' - as he says in his press. ... What's Harmsway done?
answer: A rumor - from an anonymous source - Hearsay. Idle chatter from a source you can't identify - who insists on talking only to 007. Nothing but loose talk and innuendo. More scurrilous, unsubstantiated gossip.

question: Perhaps. But it does explain how an ex-KGB agent turned illegal-arms dealer is suddenly portrayed as a long-time friend of the people. If you believe what you read in the papers.
answer: Need I remind the two of you that Elliot Harmsway - Sir Elliot Harmsway - is directly descended from the Earl of Aberdeen? That his Scottish ancestors practically invented Hong Kong - and out of sheer gratitude, Queen Victoria herself named the port "Aberdeen Harbor" in their honor?

question: Of course. ... Didn't we once investigate Harmsway?
answer: Not to mention the chaos it caused at Whitehall when his newspapers began screaming for the recall of the sitting government.

question: How will I meet the informant? I understand.
answer: There is one last thing, 007

question: Political considerations?
answer: To the best of my recollection, Mr. Bond, I suggested no such thing. In fact, I was never here.

question: .... I hate to ask, but... Did you ever think you'd miss Communism? Hopefully, it won't get that far. Okay, Saunders. What is it this time? Rocket in the leg? Machine pistol in the arm?
answer: Q's retirement party. I'd just put the knife into the cake, and -

question: Come on. I know better than that - It must do something.
answer: Well... If you insist.

question: The die is cast.
answer: Now pay attention, 007. We haven't much time to demonstrate your new Q toys.

question: How is old Q?
answer: Gone fishing.

question: Fishing?
answer: Big game fishing. Sonar torpedoes. Retirement gift from his friends at the CIA. In the meantime, perhaps this will spark your interest. Cigarette lighter. Thumb here, press here -

question: Saunders, I've lit cigarettes -
answer: Not from forty feet. The disposable lighter also contains a small self-detonation charge Depending on who - or what - you wish to dispose of. Stop fidgeting, 007. Next -

question: ... Shoelaces?
answer: Plastique explosive shoelaces. Cut them to regulate the size of the blast; totally harmless until you attach the detonator hidden in the heel of your shoe.

question: Perfect way to tie up a... 'Knotty' problem?
answer: Moving along - A typical plastic security card. Name here, magnetic information stripe here - And a code breaking microprocessor here. Swipe it through any card reader - anywhere - you're in.

question: Does it work on cash machines?
answer: It was an authorized test. I returned the money.

question: I see...
answer: Finally, your new watch

question: If you can't do the time, don't do the crime?
answer: Oh. I almost forgot. There is one last thing

question: A wedding band??? What am I supposed to be able to do with this?
answer: I believe Q's exact words were

question: ...I'll give you a ring from Venice. Till death do us part. Looking for someone?
answer: Hello, James.

question: Paris?!? What are you doing here?
answer: Is that any way to say hello?

question: I thought your specialty was good-bye.
answer: Oh, James. I've missed you -

question: Is this another one of your games?
answer: Stop it! You're hurting me! Can't you just be nice?

question: I've got half the British government breathing down my neck. I don't have time for your nonsense.
answer: Don't you even miss me? Didn't I mean anything to you?

question: Nothing. What about Elliot Harmsway? Or is this just another one of your stunts?
answer: No! He's crazy - he's insane. He hates everybody. He's got these plans - You've got to help me, James. I'm sorry. I'm sorry for everything. I know I was wrong - but you've got to protect me. I know you still love - Do you feel better now?

question: Do you? What about the uranium?
answer: It's on the boat. He's holding a press conference tomorrow. I'm so sorry, James. I promise, I'll never leave you again.

question: Shhhhh...
answer: Just hold me.

question: How do you know Harmsway?
answer: Kiss me. Bastard! Leave me alone!

question: Valentin. What an unpleasant surprise.
answer: What is it that brings you to Venezia, Mr. Bond? Business - Or somebody else's business? New mistress. So? Go! Here. Take an inch. Come. Let me buy you a drink. It's free. Two vodka martini's. Shaken. Not stirred. And you?

question: One. I must say, Valentin, capitalism seems to be treating you well.
answer: I used to sell weapons; now I buy votes. Off the record.

question: Of course. If you can't beat the government, you might as well own it.
answer: Wait - I want you to meet a friend of mine. Elliot! Elliot! Come here. Elliot Harmsway, I want to introduce you to an old friend -

question: Paris -
answer: Leave me alone! He's going to kill me!!

question: Why didn't you tell me? Why wasn't it in our files?
answer: He didn't want anyone to know. He kept it out of the papers. He said a third wife was bad for his image. You've got to protect me!

question: Go to my hotel room. I'll be there in twenty minutes.
answer: Just - say it. Say it just once.

question: One thing at a time. I'll see you in twenty minutes. Go.
answer: I believe this is what you're looking for, Colonel. Is it uranium? Absolutely. But watch - It's depleted uranium! Completely safe! A child could sleep on it. I received it from the Russian government - a by-product of their nuclear arms program - in the hopes that I could create tools for oceanographic research. It's what I was talking about Please. No harm done, Don Franco. Go upstairs, and enjoy the reception. Oh - Mr. Bond. One minute. I hope you've enjoyed this little charade.

question: Which part? The Colonel's? Or yours?
answer: A piece of advice, Mr. Bond

question: We'll see about that.
answer: Aren't you late for a meeting?

question: Good morning, Gentlemen. I'm sorry to bring you here under these circumstances, but Considering our meeting was already scheduled, this was a happy coincidence. Excellent, Number One. Build a better rat-trap, and the world truly will beat a path to your theme park. Number Two? Outstanding, Number Two. By the way - Number Five - ? Who's ahead in the American elections? Maybe it's time to publish that story about his sex life. Even things up. A close race is always better for our TV ratings. Splendid. Next... Number Three. Your report?
answer: I regret to inform you, sir, that Saddam Hussein is still demanding a bonus for his role in the Gulf War.

question: ...Haven't we already paid him for his services?
answer: Yes, sir. But he still feels his people should share in the increased profits of our news division. He has proposed an additional 500 million dollar payment.

question: ... And there's no truth that 10% of that money will go into your Swiss bank account?
answer: No sir! I swear! This is not true!!

question: You disappoint me, Number Three.
answer: Please sir. Please -

question: ...But because I am a just man, I've decided to give Mr. Hussein what he deserves. Mr. Stamper will escort you to the plane.
answer: Thank you sir! Thank you!

question: Zero one three. Due north. We're on course again.
answer: Can't see a damn thing in this fog. Rating

question: Damn. It's doing it again.
answer: What's wrong?

question: About every ninety seconds, the auto- pilot jogs us to the west. Then re-sets us to the north.
answer: Not in the Strait. How's our position? Did you check the auto-pilot?

question: The back-up does the same thing.
answer: Check it again. What about the global positioning satellite? Could there be something wrong with the signal? How is it now?

question: Seems to be back to normal, sir.
answer: A dead head. Water logged timber. Floats straight up. You sometimes see them on the east side of the channel - from the logging camps on Sumatra - but they don't usually float this far west. Muncy! Engines to half!

question: Aye-aye sir. Engines to half.
answer: Chew up a log like that in the propeller, you end up with enough paperwork to go from here to London. Twice. Punch up the radar - That's impossible! We're in the middle of the channel! Full stop!!! Call the captain! What?!?! Get me damage reports! Start the pumps!

question: The engines are gone!
answer: Sound the general alarm! Seal all compartments! Go to back up generators! Where the hell are those generators? Get those pumps working!

question: We can't hold out much longer, sir!
answer: Where the hell is the Captain?!?!

question: Slipping to stern!
answer: Abandon ship! Break radio silence! Send our position!

question: One-third of the British gold reserves?!? What kind of idiot loses - What is it? The equivalent of ten billion US dollars??? What the hell was the gold doing on that boat?
answer: We were bringing it back from Hong Kong. Under orders from the Treasury.

question: Why wasn't the ship protected?!?! Why was it sailing without radar?
answer: I resent your tone, sir. I have men who are missing -

question: Good. We have an appointment in Hong Kong.
answer: I have an excellent teacher. 'Make sure you wear the uniform'? It doesn't quite add up. The infrared satellite images. No heat, no flame, no explosion. If that boat went down where they said it did, there should have been some residual heat reading on the surface. A three-thousand ton frigate doesn't just vanish into thin air. ... Didn't Elliot Harmsway just move his headquarters to Kuala Lumpur?

question: General Li Thank you, General Li. Now I'll just sign this last document - Of course! How foolish. More bad luck. I'll just borrow yours - An old Chinese toast to our friends... Confusion to the enemy. In 48 hours, that building - and all of Hong Kong around it - will cease to exist.
answer: We should be right over it. Where? What is it? Let's make another pass. Get rid of them.

question: Morning, morning all. What have we got?
answer: The Canadian Prime Minister wants to set a lunch -

question: Pencil it in for the next trip -
answer: The American presidential candidate called to complain about that sex story -

question: Send him a $10,000 campaign contribution, and explain I have no control over what my journalists write -
answer: Your bankers want an answer about the Brazilian TV stations

question: No -
answer: The Queen invited you to dinner -

question: Yes -
answer: And the 9:30 news meeting is waiting.

question: Still nothing? Wade, what the hell are you doing here?
answer: I am not here, ol' buddy. The CIA has absolutely no knowledge of the missing ship, the missing gold, where it was going, or when it left Hong Kong.

question: That's reassuring.
answer: Hey - the world is my office.

question: Let's take a look at the body.
answer: Smells like... Coffee plants. Colorful... Shark attack?

question: I don't think so. The veins are cauterized - as if they were sealed by heat... But there are no burn marks on the flesh. It doesn't make sense. Who found the body? Ask him if it could have washed in from the west side of the Strait. You have a boat?
answer: I don't know if you'd call it a boat...

question: Something with an engine? Not oars?
answer: Step into my office. What do you want with the Harbor Master?

question: Tide and current charts. Work backward from the body - find where the ship sank. Where did you get the boat?
answer: Seized it from a guy smuggling computer chips out of Bangkok. Should have seen his rose garden

question: Over there.
answer: I think I've just seen my next future ex-wife.

question: Not if you kill us first - unless that's how you plan to leave Muffy.
answer: By the way, Jimbo - whatever happened to that girl - in Cuba - ?

question: Natalya?
answer: Yeah. Russian Minister of Transportation.

question: She married a hockey player.
answer: I envy your 'undercover' assignments.

question: We work in the dark. We do what we can. Thanks. By the way - was there anything strange the night before last? Odd weather, lost boats - ?? ...Bus problem? Thanks. I have to get these to London. Do you know this Captain Cheong?
answer: Spends his nights at the Kuala Lumpur yacht club.

question: Can you arrange a meeting?
answer: Hell. The CIA built that club. Okay gentlemen. The name of the game is 7-card Cambodian stud. Everything is wild!

question: In the Strait of Malacca, when a boat is even five minutes late, one begins to worry, Mr. Bond.
answer: I know. Pirates from Sumatra want the cargo; smugglers from Thailand and Burma want the ships.

question: Sometimes kill the crew; other times - Torture them.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: The Kuala Lumpur ferry was 35 miles off-course that night. Captain blamed the auto-pilot; I suspected he was drunk - until the Sumatra ferry captain had same problem.
answer: Did you test the auto-pilots? The satellite positioning receiver?

question: Next morning. Both boats. Nothing wrong. My 90 year old grandfather thinks 'Ghost in the computer - Silicon Dragon.'
answer: I appreciate your time -

question: Maybe you should talk to Sidney Winch. Owns a marine salvage company. Nobody knows more about the Strait.
answer: Where can I find him?

question: Bourbon. Neat.
answer: I wonder if you handle your liquor more carefully than you handle your boat.

question: Sometimes, you just have to plunge into things. Be reckless.
answer: - And I bet you always leave turmoil in your wake.

question: Have we met?
answer: This afternoon. Our boats practically kissed in the harbor. James Bond.

question: Sidney Winch.
answer: Vodka martini, shaken not stirred. And another for you?

question: No. But you can buy a drink for my friend, Taro.
answer: Boyfriend?

question: Chaperone. I'm waiting for my dinner date.
answer: Pity. Bring him whatever he wants.

question: So what brings you to Kuala Lumpur, Mr. Bond? Wait - don't tell me
answer: Actually, I'm here on business. You might say it was a... Golden opportunity.

question: And exactly what business are you in, Mr. Bond?
answer: Insurance. Lloyds of London.

question: The Strait can be a very dangerous place, Mr. Bond. A few words scribbled on a piece of paper in London doesn't carry a lot of value out here. Including life insurance.
answer: I'll keep that in mind.

question: I see my date is here. And I think Mr. Bond is ready to leave.
answer: Nice to run into you again.

question: Yo! Jimbo! I won five hundred - What happened?
answer: He tied one on. Q! How are you? I'm sorry. It was a national emergency - Do you have any idea of what any of that means? In English? Do I have to dial '9' to get out? - Four wheel drive? ... 17 Beverage cup holders? I must say, Q, you seem to be doing rather well in your retirement. Slow down. We're close.

question: I dunno, Jimbo. It can't be out here. How could they get this far off course?
answer: Who knows? Fog, night...

question: They'd never sail this close to the shore.
answer: Wait a minute - I've got it. There! Off the port bow! Cut the engines! It's about two- hundred fifty feet down.

question: Two-fifty's pretty deep for air. You should really be using mixed gases.
answer: I'll make a bounce dive. If I can keep my bottom time short, I'll be all right. Keep your eye out for pirates.

question: I got you covered.
answer: That's reassuring.

question: - Shut up!
answer: You have to excuse Miss Winch

question: No?
answer: No. First, because I don't think it's in your nature. And second, because there's no gold down there.

question: Every wharf-rat from here to Hong Kong knows what's on that boat and I'm claiming it. One-third of that gold is mine.
answer: That's fine, but - even a little London girl knows that one third of nothing is still nothing.

question: Was he carrying anything? Search him. Do I have to do everything around here?
answer: I hope so. I hope you'll be gentle.

question: Think about mom.
answer: ... Unusual technique.

question: And what do you call this?
answer: - The family jewels?

question: If I were you -
answer: - You're not.

question: Just remember
answer: Thank you. "Now hear this

question: Who's in charge here?
answer: I am. What do you want?

question: You have precisely one minute to pull up your anchor and be under way.
answer: Forget it. No way. I got here first.

question: Thanks for your message. And you're Bond?
answer: Yes -

question: Guard! Arrest these men! Escort them to the cutter!
answer: Wait a minute -

question: Get them out of here. If he says one word, shoot him.
answer: What's your name?

question: Captain Morton.
answer: My name is Sidney Winch, and -

question: Good for you, Miss Winch. You now have exactly 30 seconds to get this rust bucket out of here.
answer: I know my rights. These are international waters. The British Navy abandoned that boat, and I'm claiming it. Under international law, I have the right to salvage what's on that wreck.

question: Fifteen seconds. Perhaps you should consider hiring an attorney.
answer: I was an attorney!

question: Hmmm. I suppose this is a step above that profession. Ten seconds. Are you leaving?
answer: No.

question: You leave me no alternative. Cut her anchor.
answer: You won't get away with this!

question: Good-day, Miss Winch. I advise you to get some steam up - before you run aground.
answer: You bastards! Believe me - you haven't heard the last of me!

question: It's no trick, Mr. Wade. I've got half a mind to throw both of you in the brig.
answer: Don't you think you're overreacting?

question: Yes. The famous James Bond. I've heard all about you, sir. You were under direct orders to act as an observer - and yet you had to go off, on your own, like some half-assed CIA cowboy - Endangering the gold, attracting that lunatic woman, and then putting in a distress call for us to save your bloody hide.
answer: ...That's all well and good, Captain, save for one thing

question: What are you talking about? We went through all this and the ship isn't even down there?
answer: Yes, the ship is down there. But the gold is gone.

question: That's absurd! It took two squads of forty men fifteen days to load that gold.
answer: I know what I saw -

question: I'm not certain... But I think there's someone I want to press for some answers in Kuala Lumpur. Bond. Who is this?
answer: Elliot Harmsway! I heard you were in K.L. and thought we might get together for a chat...

question: How did you get this number?
answer: Oh, please, Mr. Bond. We live in the information age! Information is currency - and with the right currency, you can have any piece of information. Besides I own the phone company. What do you say? Twenty minutes?

question: I'm on my way.
answer: Let's find out exactly what he knows.

question: James Bond to see Elliot Harmsway. I'd prefer to park it myself. Temperamental. Practically has a mind of its own.
answer: Mr. Bond! Nice to see you.

question: Sir Elliot.
answer: Come. Let's get out of the noise. - I'll give you a tour of the building, then we'll talk. It's funny, Mr. Bond. Of all the things I own, nothing gives me as much enjoyment as my newspapers.

question: Yes... A man with ink in his veins, and blood on his hands.
answer: We print 31 newspapers here; another two-hundred-and-seventy at satellite plants around the world.

question: ... And how many of those newspapers carried Paris Harmsway's obituary?
answer: All of them, Mister Bond... After you? Before I became involved with Paris, she was always involved with the most inappropriate' men... Playboys. Thrill seekers. Middle aged Peter Pans who only brought out the worst in her.

question: I see.
answer: I tried to save her. But she remained a manic depressive

question: I wonder if it runs in the family.
answer: The only difference between a psychopath and a genius, Mr. Bond, is the degree of success. Still, I do miss her. I only wish she could have lived to see all this.

question: I can feel your pain.
answer: By the way - what is it that brings you to Kuala Lumpur, Mister Bond?

question: Sightseeing.
answer: I call this the Rogue's gallery.

question: Yes. I can see
answer: My third great Uncle - the Earl of Aberdeen - negotiated the purchase of Hong Kong from the Chinese. His son-in-law - George Harmsway - made the first family fortune, running opium into Shanghai... His son, Thomas, who lost it, smoking the opium... And my grandfather Henry, who opened the first telegraph station, and published the colony's first English newspaper. It was a city of unlimited possibility.

question: So why did you leave?
answer: Because it's a dying city. Since the Chinese take-over, who knows what can happen tomorrow? In any case, this is my father, Charles Welcome to the new world order, Mr. Bond. Churchill had his armies; Caesar had his legions; I have my divisions

question: And still not a thing to watch. ...Although it must be fun to have all those satellites.
answer: They're merely tools to disseminate information.

question: Or disinformation... If you wanted to, say, beam down a signal to send a ship off course? Maybe one degree a minute?
answer: Fantastic idea Mr. Bond! Perhaps I should buy it for a book! It's totally preposterous, but - You amuse me. ...And now perhaps I can amuse you. Let's see... First we have this James Bond... I believe he's a field adjuster for Lloyd's of London... Then we have this James Bond. ... Licensed to Kill... Not a bad title for that book... Or perhaps you'd prefer this James Bond - Who I believe they call "007." You see, Mr. Bond, you and I are both men of action. But your era is passing. Words are the new weapons; satellites the new artillery. And make no mistake about it

question: ...Words to live by?
answer: Your choice. Look at the time! Come. There's someone I want you meet - about a story I'm thinking of publishing. Hello, dear. I'm sorry I took so long -

question: Don't pout, Sidney. I invited him here hoping he might shed some light on your story. He's from 'Lloyd's of London.' ...Aren't you, Mr. Bond?
answer: He's not going to tell the truth! He was diving for the gold!

question: It seems - Mr. Bond - that Miss Winch has told me the most incredible story Obviously, the British government denies all of this -
answer: - I told you! He was there! -

question: - But as I've explained to Sidney, without proof, there's just no story. Don't you agree Mr. Bond?
answer: But I have proof! You ran out of here so fast, I didn't get to show you.

question: ... Do you have a gun?
answer: What?

question: You heard me. A gun? I left mine in the car.
answer: That's funny

question: Listen to me! I'm a British secret service agent. And we have about two minutes before Harmsway kills both of us.
answer: Has anyone ever suggested that you're a paranoid psychotic?

question: Harmsway sank that ship and stole the gold. It's on the Sea Dolphin II. And thanks to your little show and tell - - giving him the evidence - We're the only ones who can tie him to the crime.
answer: Elliot Harmsway is my Uncle!

question: Blood or Dutch?
answer: He was my father's best friend!

question: He's killed closer.
answer: You are seriously deranged.

question: Maybe. But why are we going up instead of down? Sidney, come with me -
answer: Not if my life depended on it. Thank God! He's crazy!

question: Not if my life depended on it. Thank God! He's crazy!
answer: Does he have a gun?

question: No.
answer: Good -

question: This is a mistake!
answer: Shut up!

question: Shut up!
answer: Need a lift?

question: Help me up.
answer: ... I'd try the stairs.

question: Out.
answer: JAMES! Okay. So it wasn't a mistake. What do we do now? Offer them dinner?!?!

question: Come here. You shoot. I'll cook. Aim that way. Shoot back! One second - ... How did you get into marine salvage?
answer: My father left me the business. I used to be a divorce lawyer in New York City.

question: Not a lot of difference.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Either way, you're taking the goods from dead hulks. Let's go - Damn!
answer: What the hell does that do?

question: We'll go down close to the sky bridge. We may be able to swing over and use it for cover.
answer: No way. I sail. I do not fly.

question: ... Sometimes, you just have to take the plunge.
answer: All I know is one thing

question: One thing at a time.
answer: What now? And don't give me some movie clich like 'trust me.'

question: Trust me. Let's go -
answer: We're going to bounce off that thing!

question: What about the elevators?
answer: We tried that already. Remember?

question: You know, this is as much your fault as it is mine.
answer: Sidney, we don't have time for this -

question: Sure! Just when I want to talk - Not that I would have believed you -
answer: Put your back to the railing. Sit up on it.

question: Are you listening to me?
answer: Put your arms around my neck. Lock your legs around my waist.

question: ... We have time for that?
answer: Sometimes you just have to -

question: Don't say it. Is this - like - a normal day for you?
answer: It's a lousy job, but - The only reason I stay is for the health benefits.

question: Oh, please, Sidney. There's a hundred billion dollars at stake. Besides, I never really liked your father that much. He cheated at cards.
answer: Are your guards really going to kill a helpless girl?

question: My guards are from South Africa, Mr. Bond. This is their chance to get even with the formerly 'Great' Britain. Now both of you. Put your hands on your heads, and step forward.
answer: What did you do, Harmsway? Make some deal with the Chinese government for the gold?.. Was the radioactive uranium I found in Venice part of it?

question: Questions, questions, Mr. Bond... Which I'm afraid I've neither the time, nor the inclination to answer. Take them out to the jungle and -
answer: I forgot to mention

question: Kill it! Shoot the damn thing -
answer: Here. You shoot. I'll drive.

question: Here. You shoot. I'll drive.
answer: ...You know, that's another reason you're probably not in a successful relationship.

question: Another reason??? Did I miss something???
answer: You insist on calling all the shots. And by the way

question: Start the grinders.
answer: ...So that's what the weapons grade uranium was for.

question: Precisely, Mr. Bond. In a matter of minutes, the boring device will arrive at the core of the reactor... And when the radioactive blades cut into the plutonium -
answer: - Instant melt-down.

question: I'll meet you on the boat, south of Lantau Island.
answer: Take the men. I can finish alone.

question: You come with me - You stay here.
answer: We'll cut through the last gate, then set it on auto-pilot. Check it out. Be careful.

question: What the hell is going on?
answer: It's Bond!

question: Kill him! Finish it!
answer: You're mine now. I'm going to do this slowly -

question: Stamper! Report in!
answer: I never believe what I read in the newspapers.

question: Pity you'll miss your obituary.
answer: Where is she, Harmsway?

question: You want to kill me, Bond? Go ahead.
answer: Where is she Harmsway? -

question: What is it, Bond? You haven't the guts?
answer: You spineless paper tiger - Where is she, Harmsway?!? Or did you kill her like Paris?

question: What do you mean, you'd rather die alone?
answer: I didn't say when I want to die - ... Yes???

question: Before we go any further here, Mr. Bond, from Lloyds of London, I just want to get two things straight.
answer: ... Yes?

question: First, that boat is in international waters. I'm claiming it for salvage. One-third of that gold is mine.
answer: And number two?

question: If you think we're going to have some kind of 'life affirming' romance here just because we cheated death, let me be clear
answer: And when might that be?
